title.label: I own this on both PC and ios

content.label: Great game with active developers. I can’t wait to see what future updates bring
This game is my jam! That’s what I’m talkin’ about! Woo-yeah!!! UH!

The first star traders game was my absolute favorite but a few years ago it became very glitchy and would crash frequently on my iPhone X. So happy there is an indirect sequel with a ton of improvements and additions. Also huge props to Trese brothers for creating such great games that are reasonably priced and are updated frequently. Also thank you for being so active with the community around your games.
Best update yet totally awesome how the developers continue to support this amazing and awesome game.

I really want to love this game. But the bugs make it unplayable. First it was fuel consumption, now it’s Reputation. (How does adding 4 reputation to a base of 0 result in a -6? Not once, but multiple times with multiple NPCs) I really enjoy playing but not if I have to delete the game and restart just as I get to a fun level. 
I’ll check back later to see if it’s been fixed, but until then I’ll play something else.

This game is magnificent. It is a turn-based RPG that combines two of my favorite things- the Wild West and the Millennium Falcon. 

Many moons ago, I downloaded a free demo of the original star traders RPG. It was an unassuming game with very simple graphics, and I enjoyed it enough that I downloaded it again each time I got a new phone for over a decade. Recently I upgraded my phone again, and discovered the long-awaited sequel (which, after a decade, I had written off) to the old indie game I loved. It is everything I hoped for and more.

All the elements I loved from the old game are on steroids- the hokey charm, the feeling of desperation as I hold my ship together, zipping around the galaxy looking for work that isn’t TOO unsavory, staying one step ahead of the authorities and a few centimeters from a frozen death in the void of space.

Let me tell you about permadeath. On the higher difficulties, there is only one save file, and when your captain dies that file is deleted. Permanently. That mechanic makes this game feel absolutely real. You will get more invested in your captain and your crew than you ever did for Master Chief or Laura Croft, and when one of your people dies, they die forever. It’s sad. Legit. 

You could turn permadeath off, but IMO you would be doing yourself a disservice, because that pulls you into the immersive experience. Each of your crew had personality traits that affect their stats and their gameplay. Often it’s very minor, and it seldom feels burdensome, but I have had to fire experienced crewmen because they got addicted and mean- one too many weeks in the void. Some traits can be fixed by doctors- it is the future, after all- but that’s pricy, doctors that do it aren’t everywhere, and there isn’t always enough coin to do what you want. Sometimes you will have to make hard choices.

One last thing that I appreciate is that this is turn based and solo. If I’m on airplane mode, that’s fine. If I have to put my phone down because something comes up, no big deal. There is no penalty for having a life and not saving because it effectively saves every time you give an order.

title.label: One of the Best Games for iPad

content.label: This is an amazing game from a developer that really cares and listens to its customers.  Infinite replay ability with procedurally created universes.  Different captain classes for different experiences and play styles.  One price and no nickel and dining you with in-app purchases.  Lots of updates to improve and enhance the game using user feedback.  Just buy it!

I’d suggest heavily supporting Trese Brothers games.  These guys are serious about their games and serious about their community. This specific game is the best (and basically only) game of its type on IOS.  Their lore is incredible and their mechanics are constantly improving.  Thank you to Trese brothers for putting out a consistently excellent experience.
Star Traders Frontiers is my go-to game when I have time. I also play on my iPad and think Star Traders could benefit from having iCloud saves.
I have played it through a couple of time and really enjoyed it. I strongly recommend this game if a turn-based game is your jam.

The playability is nearly perfect for portable gaming. The turn based play with instant saving is perfect for playing over any time period. Easily interrupted. The game is very replay-able with a variety of character and ship builds. Definitely my favorite IOS game right now.
Buy this game now and watch the hours melt away! Has a bit of a learning curve but once you understand the mechanics it’s very rewarding and the possibilities seem endless.

title.label: Good if you’re into slow grind

content.label:
I have gone back and forth on this game. 
Pros: It is incredibly well made with a staggering level of detail in terms of the universe and also managing/upgrading your ship and crew.  It runs very well, and I have never experienced glitches or crashes.  The art is also really cool.  The stories are well designed.  They don’t feel hokey or childish but rather embrace a complex system of alliances and enemies that make each play through potentially different.  I like being able to choose gender of your character, as I am a woman and I get tired of being forced to play male characters.
Cons: this is a very slow grind, and after awhile the turn based combat, whether between ships or crews, gets old.  This is not so for everyone and many will not mind this.  
Space travel also becomes repetitive and as you progress through each mission requires multiple jumps and often visits to planets to refuel on the way.  This just got boring to me after a while.  
An auto save feature and a way to shortcut through travel, combat etc if you want would really help open this game to a more casual audience.  I couldn’t even begin to scratch the surface of this game until quarantine cleared my calendar. Just starting out is so difficult.   This is not a universe one can fully explore right away. You can easily find yourself in a rabbit hole where you have no money, no fuel, no chops in combat and your ship is teeming with mutiny.  I had to restart 5 or 6 times.  The learning curve is steep and death comes easy if you venture to an area above your skill level.  I finally started with the option that gives you a good ship and that helped me get going.  
I hope this honest review helps people decide.  This is a game some will love, but I think I will be uninstalling soon.

Really great turn-based game with so much randomization it keeps you guessing, plotting, cussing, making notes, restarting, honing lol...  I would give this 5* if it was a free game; since it has kind of a high price tag I think it could use a few improvements:
1) still no retirement button for captains that have been out there awhile?  I saw a few threads online from a couple of years back mentioning this, and so far I haven’t come across an end-of-career option so what gives?
2) when I’m flying my Sword Battlecruiser around, why am I still attacked by spies, bounty hunters, zealots and the like flying ships that I can just chew up, spit out and be on my way?  I know there are components I can add to my ship to reduce random encounters, but why would these insects be attacking something that can so obviously stomp them?  Even if they’re extremely hostile, they should just be hurling strong language at me from afar.
3) could definitely use an art upgrade.  I’m not expecting cutting-edge graphics but the character art is just a bad joke.

Anyway, still enjoying the game, and I *do* think it’s worth the price, especially given that it’s still being actively developed.  Just would like to see these 3 things improved :)

This is one of the most underrated titles on here. I have been playing Trese Brothers games for a long time now, hey continue to focus on improved gameplay and storyline, putting the gamer first and foremost in game developing. There are lot of great titles and this game is by far one of the best games I have ever played with a ton of replay value. 

You will not be disappointed purchasing this game.

title.label: Great, but not fully optimized for iphone

content.label: In some cases buttons are either invisible or behind another button, great game anyway

This is an amazing game with incredibly depth and an ever evolving persistent world. It’s clearly had a ton of work put into it by devs who care about making great games.

That being said the current version suffers a bit from UI problems.

Specifically, playing on an iPhone 8 running IOS 13 I’ve noticed an issue where menus can not be scrolled. In ship combat for example when selecting a flight plan for craft  it’s impossible to scroll through the list of flight plans and the ones at the top are half cut off.

The same issue occurs when recruiting crew, where half of the window is cut off and it’s impossible to scroll up to view more options.

The game itself deserves five stars, and I’ll update this review if they ever fix the UI problems.

title.label: Crashes when trying to load save game

content.label: I’m using an iPad 6

One of the most interactive, immersive, and enjoyable games of the genre. One feature which would be awesome is to customize your starting officers, either by attributes or jobs (ie: why does my ENG, who won’t be in combat, have a 30 quickness and is Ex-Military, but my Doc who is going to be a Combat Medic, has an 18 quickness and has the Wanderlust trait. I’d love to just swap their starting jobs). When I wanted to play a combat focused captain, I ended up scrapping and ‘rerolling’ 20+ times until I had a starting officer trio I felt could take on the jyeeta by endgame. Even a title screen which says “here are your 3-4 starting officers, pick whom you would like to be the ENG, Doc, and QM, would be awesome!

Just some feedback; love the game

Another update come and gone without being able to use my full screen. Not only that, but they put fake screen shots up that have the rounded corners as if they actually have support for said screens. Very disappointed.

In an age where gaming is saturated with cookie cutter sword and sorcery titles, a pair of brothers dares to be unique!

But seriously, great game, crushing difficulty curve, especially if you aren't used to planning things out. This game does not hold your hand.

Could we Bring Cyber Knights Elite To iPhone???
 IM A Big Fan
Great refreshing fun game without in-app purchases, stress-free because it’s single player, and you can play without internet, so go ahead and book the long flights!
Great game in general
Loving this game

This game seemed like it was right up my alley but after a few months of on and off attempting to figure it out I gave up.

It’s very confusing. You get too much too soon with little explanation about what’s going on. The learning curve is just overwhelmingly brutal. I’m 36 and have been playing video games since I could pick up a controller. This mess of a game just seems half finished. Half the game is just making sure you have enough fuel to get around. The UI is messy and jumbled, ship and crew combat is atrocious and boring. I love turn based games but this? Nah.

They really need to rework the beginning of the game to ease the player into everything instead of throwing you into it. The way it is now it feels like you skipped the first quarter of the game.

It’s too late for me to get a refund so just be warned. This is not an easy game to play. Heck it’s not even a hard game to play. It’s a brutal game to play and not in a fun or challenging way.

title.label: One of the best games ever on iOS

content.label: Absolutely love this game.  What a cool world they have created.  I bought all there other games just to support them.  Can be a trader or a pirate or anything in between. Love it!

The Dry Dock Menu is not properly optimized and about half of the information is cut off. Please fix. I am using iPhone 7 Plus. Also there is a glitch with the sound effects. The music still plays but the sound effects cut out completely if you go to a different app, take a phone call, hit the home button and come back to the game etc.

title.label: I would literally like to pay them more $$

content.label:
And I hope that doesn’t change why the Trese Bros make games. Because this game is fricking B.E.A.U.T.I.F.U.L. 

At this point, it is functionally a flawless, perfect, intensely engaging game on all levels. 

Two fast caveats: Interdictors still aren’t functioning for me outside of completing their bombing runs or applying buffs/debuffs. My Interdictors still don’t interdict (lol) missiles, torpedoes, nor do they engage in any way with incoming craft. And it’s actually a tiiiiiny but sucky, just for someone who has been AWE’ED(whaaa?) by the carrier-based play available. OhmyGAAAAWD it literally got to become another game to me, and I’ve pegged another Capt at 40 (not at ALL on all the difficulties mind you, not at all. The void is FUHREAKING UNFORGIVING, people, and your “literally indestructible” captain will have a weak spot that you missed. And some day, some fateful day where you didn’t even realize that the last thing you(r captain) would ever eat was an English muffin, with melted butter, and whatever strawberry jam or jellylike substance that’s still made with the real fruit. 

Then, your captain dies. 

You failed your save. “What save you ask?” Welcome to the Void, Traveler. 

My second caveat is actually null and voided with the very latest update. And believe me, I have let my life suffer for this game (short term, all short term, and thanks to no game mechanics-abusing IAPs there were NO financial setbacks from playing this game too much!)

I’m googling the Trese Brothers rn, and see if they have a Patreon or something I can bequeath a few of my actually literally precious few dollars these days to their work. Because it is f’ing beautiful work. It is functionally flawless, ladies and gents and all the rest of us.

title.label: If it says Trese Brother’s, BUY it. Excellent game, you won’t be disappointed

content.label: Seriously, these devs know how to make a game. Great community presence and awesome updates. I absolutely love this game. It can get overwhelming at times due to the amount of detail and moving pieces involved, but the interface is great and information is always a touch away.

title.label: Huge ambition, but a little flat

content.label:
Steep learning curve leads to several scrapped starts as you ease into this game. I give the devs credit for the massive amount of freedom players have in this game. My only fault with it, is that it lacks excitement. The daring ship is massively capable of blowing anything out of the sky that you might meet... it’s just a redundant tap, tap, tap, wait, tap, tap, tap, wait (rinse, lather, repeat 8x) til combat finally ends. I’ve played it about ten hours and just don’t have the drive to put in another then to see if it gets better. 

It’s a good game, don’t get me wrong, and it’ll hold your attention for a while unless you are a drooling moron who needs a hand holding tutorial just to know which side of the toilet paper to use. But, without SOME form of excitement/action/meaningful progress, it doesn’t make my top 100.

I bought this game on Steam originally and played it all day.  I thought to myself, “You know, this game would be great on mobile”.  Searched on the app store on a whim honestly... and yay!  Now it’s my on my phone too.  Fantastic space trader, space pirate, politics, explorer, etc game.  Story is pretty good so far.  I don’t know who to trust and rep actually matters!
Best space rpg simulator

title.label: An awesome board and dice style game with stats calculator

content.label: I couldn’t ask for much more, other than having additional and optional 1st person battle mode for shooting and defending which would make it more interactive if you wanted to try finger dexterity skills as opposed to just dice roll. Thanks for the great game!
Nicely put together, just not my thing!
Anime
Great game, great value!  Can be a little repetitive, but overall well worth the money.

title.label: Good potential but big flaws hold it back

content.label: The game is deep - there’s clearly a lot of thought invested in this. But a few issues make it tedious: the fact that there is no true “save” is one of the most catastrophic developer choices I’ve ever seen. Due to bugs in engagement balancing, you can occasionally get rolled by another ship or crew.  And the result? Perma-death or massive loss. This takes the fun out of the game. You can spend days building up a ship and crew only to see them destroyed due to a bug and no means of restoring it. Also, the crew fighting (land) engagements are well below the quality of the rest of the game and feel like early 90’s gaming mechanics.

Only other thing I really want is more hard-core / fierce battle faces for the crew.

I want some Terminator killing machine types for battle - not some Kurt Colbain clones. ;) 

Oh and to select colors for armor like in Templar elite .....

title.label: Great game overall with minor flaws

content.label:
I love this game; it reminds me of the old "Starflight.". I've pretty much been playing it non-stop for months.  But it's not perfect, which sometimes leads to some frustration.  I'll cover these below:

Pros:  The ability to customize evetything!  Your Captain, crew, ship, equipment.
The totally open nature of play; you don't have to do ANY of the story missions.
Absorbing main story lines.
Great ship and crew combat; stylized and simple in mechanics, but detailed in options and customizable to suit your style.
The talent system and faction rank/permit system that allows you to avoid most hostile encounters as time goes on (see below).
Developer support; updates, great online boards with developer presence!

Cons:  The card games!  These are ridiculously biased towards bad events, and talents for replacing/removing cards don't increase the probability of mission success, they only remove or alter a negative.  This is a major frustration since EVERYTHING requires the card game.
The random encounters actually seem to increase as the game progresses, making it more and more difficult to perform routine tasks like flying around.  This frustration is mitigated by the talents you get and your faction rank/permits, so isn't as much a frustration as the card game (though a xeno or hostile bounty hunter can still ruin yor day!).

The whole game is big and complex. You’re not just playing a sci fi rpg, but the environment is its own eco system, with factions gaining or losing ground, with or without your involvement. Its very dynamic.

Subtracted one star because...
-In dire need of a more interesting story arc
-Needs a fast-forward button for long distances and crew battles

This game is so deep and fun! I can’t recommend it enough. It has all the elements of a great RPG. Plus the devs are consistent on updates even after the game has been out for a while. Really, stop reading this review and give it a shot!

I am impressed by the sheer depth of Star Traders Frontiers. It is easily the most full-featured iPad game I’ve played, with lots of replay value and countless strategies to try. The developers keep supporting and updating it, with the iPad version never too far behind the PC. 

Like others, I have my gripes with the RNG and difficulty setting based unlocks, but I am having fun despite these personal misses. Reading the forums it seems the Trese Brothers listen to their customers, so I expect my enjoyment will continue for some time as features continue to be added and balance issues are addressed.

Highly recommended to anyone looking for an in-depth strategy gaming experience!

I’ve been playing this game for a couple months now on the same play through and am still not bored. Tres Brothers have done a great job of continuing to update the game and adding new ships and other content as well as bug fixes. My only minor complaint is that you can’t customize your ships color. That’s far from game breaking though and is still well worth the money.
Best mobile game i ever played.
Could still use a lot of rebalancing, but otherwise an excellent game without a single IAP.  Taking ships shouldn’t be such a difficult talent to achieve though.

Came across a weird glitch I think. Was working for someone, had two missions I was working on, when all of a sudden when I got to my destination the missions had vanished. I went back but the contact had also disappeared. Is that supposed to happen? Why did she disappear? Also for some reason have had a couple mutinies without cause. Like high moral and not short on crew, so if everybody is happy and we are fully staffed then why am I getting mutinies? Wasn’t even after a battle or anything jus random mutiny while traveling. And not sure if glitch or if Im doing it wrong but even if I get the perk and proper permits to capture a prize ship it dosent let me. Are the prize ships the main battle ships or the small ships launched durring battle? If its the small ones could you add some sort of system where we cab tow a captured main ship back to a port and repair and keep it or sell it for money. It would also be nice if all the dry docks were connected because I had left a ship at one before and wasn’t able to find it again. Maybe at least make a system that tells you where all your owned ships are? Also could you add some sort of help page so I don’t have to go through apple to report glitches? I feel like these aren’t usually read. Anyway aside from those glitches the game is really fun and I have been enjoying playing it.

I have bought hundreds of games on iOS, and own most of the “epic” hardcore strategy and role play games on iOS. This game ranks near the top in terms of value, gameplay, detail, and fun. I tend to steer away from sci-fi genre, but am so so glad that I took a chance on this one. We need to reward the Trese brothers with positive reviews and purchases so they and other studios will make more games like this for iOS. If you have ANY interest at all in this type of game, YOU WILL NOT BE DISAPPOINTED WITH THIS PURCHASE!

The games starts out great and there are clear missions. You know where to go and what to do, but that changes fast. The missions start becoming vague. Your mission is to hunt a pirate, but your not sure where. You have steps in another mission, but the mission display doesn't give much info. Maybe you need to be a kid with nothing better to do than memorize the galaxy, but I just want a fun game to play. I like complex, but I'm spending hours doing nothing in the game now. Not very fun.

title.label: The 2/3 of a game you get at purchase is very good...

content.label:
Clearly a labor of love, the devs continue to update this game every week or so. And not just to patch bugs or refine mechanics—they keep adding new content like storylines, ships, classes, quests, equipment, etc.

Unfortunately, you’re probably never going to get to use quite a bit of that content, because it’s locked behind achievements and linked to inflated difficulty levels.

Some achievement criteria can be met simply by successfully navigating the storyline (something the game doesn’t necessarily require you to do, btw, which is nice). Others require you to do a “sprint” run, where you put together a captain and crew with a very specific skill set to meet requirements within a limited timeframe (e.g. blockade 50 planets in the first two years of gametime).

Now, so far, none of these elements are gamebreakers, but: 1) RNG plays a huge role in every encounter/interaction in this game, and 2) most of the achievements can only be unlocked with permadeath set to “on.” This combination means that, if you’re trying to unlock the full game you’ve purchased, you’re going to be playing the complete first era or two of the storyline a LOT. Even when things are going well, the RNG gods will often suddenly dump an alien battleship or elite terrorist squad in your lap well before you’ve had a chance to build up your ship/characters to the point where they have even a slim chance of survival.

And that’s where permadeath pushes the game over the edge from ‘challenging’ to ‘downright frustrating.’ A single bad dice roll can easily cause a cascade failure where the in-game equivalent of stubbing your toe snowballs into a complete slaughter of your entire crew within just a couple rounds of action, and then it’s back to the character creation screen. The first time it happens, it’s hilarious. The 147th time it happens, you start thinking that getting your taxes done early might be a fun alternative way to spend your time.

Of course, you can turn permadeath off, and as long as you’re okay with leaving numerous ships and starting contacts/professions unavailable for play that’s a viable option. If you want to use everything you purchased, however, you’re going to be required to play the first few missions dozens and dozens and DOZENS of times.  The game is good enough that you might still come back to it after taking a break from it for a month or two; at some point, you WILL have to choose between either taking a break from it or throwing your phone/tablet through a window in frustration.
